added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from openstack.tests.functional.shared_file_system import base class ShareTypeTest(base.BaseSharedFileSystemTest): def test_share_types_create_get_update_delete(self): #: Create and assert share type myShareType = self.create_share_type( name="test_default1", extra_specs={ "driver_handles_share_servers": "False" }, required_extra_specs={ "driver_handles_share_servers": "False" }, is_public=True, description=None, is_default=False) self.assertEqual(True, myShareType.is_public) self.assertEqual("test_default1", myShareType.name) self.assertEqual(None, myShareType.description) self.assertIs(False, myShareType.is_default) self.assertEqual({ "driver_handles_share_servers": "False"}, myShareType.extra_specs) self.assertEqual({ "driver_handles_share_servers": "False"}, myShareType.required_extra_specs) #: Test list share types sts = self.conn.shared_file_system.share_type() self.assertGreater(len(list(sts)), 0) for st in sts: for attribute in ('id', 'name', 'description'): self.assertTrue(hasattr(st, attribute)) self.assertIsInstance(getattr(st, attribute), str) for attribute in ('is_default', 'share_type_access:is_public'): self.assertTrue(hasattr(st, attribute)) self.assertIsInstance(getattr(st, attribute), bool) for attribute in ('required_extra_specs', 'extra_specs'): self.assertTrue(hasattr(st, attribute)) self.assertIsInstance(getattr(st, attribute), object) #: Get and assert share type get_shareType = self.conn.share.get_share_type(myShareType.id) self.assertEqual(myShareType.is_public, get_shareType.is_public) self.assertEqual(myShareType.name, get_shareType.name) self.assertEqual(myShareType.description, get_shareType.description) self.assertEqual(myShareType.is_default, get_shareType.is_default) self.assertEqual(myShareType.extra_specs, get_shareType.extra_specs) self.assertEqual( myShareType.required_extra_specs, get_shareType.required_extra_specs) #: Update and assert share type new_desc = "testing" new_name = "update" update_share_type = self.conn.share.update_share_type( myShareType.id, name=new_name, description=new_desc) self.assertEqual(new_name, update_share_type.name) self.assertEqual(new_desc, update_share_type.description)

commit_message:
[DNM] non nested virt jammy nodes with workaround v2

Jammy nested virt nodes have issues[1] so
we can't run jobs on those.
focal nested virt jobs now started to have
issues due to py38 drop support[2]

non-nested virt nodes have memory constraints
due to qemu>=5.0.0 so need the dependent workaround.

Create seperate jobs to run slow tests as
all the tests cannot be run together with
3 hour job timeouts.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1999249
[2] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/2017478
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/868419
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/881580

Change-Id: I6ba856ae02fe7cc27483280f34c3cef8555d5c7c

commit_message:
[doc] Update releasing tool location

I've stopped proposing PRs to original repos as their review
takes really a while now.

With that I'm updating location of current version of tooling.

Change-Id: Ie4f168fbe3f2b0bc74aef3ca0700b2cffdbf752a

subject: Define backup randomized delay in defaults
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-04-20 12:09:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-galera_server/commit/41df9e82e661356f39ba49e25949952cbaeb39c5', 'message': 'Define backup randomized delay in defaults

Omit can not be used in timer options, since this is simple mapping
that is passed to the unit file. With that, omit is resolved to a
randomly named omit_place_holder  that ends up in a template.

Se we define default delay to 0, which is default systemd behaviour [1]

[1] https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd.timer.html#RandomizedDelaySec=

commit_message:
Define backup randomized delay in defaults

Omit can not be used in timer options, since this is simple mapping
that is passed to the unit file. With that, omit is resolved to a
randomly named omit_place_holder  that ends up in a template.

Se we define a delay to 0, which is default systemd behaviour [1]

[1] https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd.timer.html#RandomizedDelaySec=

Change-Id: Ib242e66cfb4a24b7e93144e382e50f124015e3bf

commit_message:
Test capabilites for srbac feature

Changed the test to keep convention without abstract methods
Also remvoed base.BaseVolumeTest inheritance, to isolate RBAC tests from
the normal tests while they are developed, even though this could be
revisited in the future the base classes for API tests in
cinder-tempest-plugin could be unified.

Change-Id: I7020487fcdb0a8e34be92a2b0f110b885cbeb339
Signed-off-by: Yosi Ben Shimon <ybenshim@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-tempest-plugin refs/changes/83/881383/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from tempest.config import CONFclass VolumeV3RbacCapabilityTests(rbac_base.VolumeV3RbacBaseTests): @classmethod def skip_checks(cls): super(VolumeV3RbacCapabilityTests, cls).skip_checks() if not CONF.volume_feature_enabled.backup: raise cls.skipException("Cinder backup feature disabled") def _get_capabilities(self, expected_status): self.do_request( 'show_backend_capabilities', expected_status=expected_status, host=host_name ) class ProjectReaderTests(VolumeV3RbacCapabilityTests): self._get_capabilities(expected_status=exceptions.Forbidden) class ProjectMemberTests(VolumeV3RbacCapabilityTests): credentials = ['project_member', 'project_admin', 'system_admin'] @decorators.idempotent_id('dbaf51de-fafa-4f55-875f-7537524489ab') def test_get_capabilities(self): self._get_capabilities(expected_status=exceptions.Forbidden) class ProjectAdminTests(VolumeV3RbacCapabilityTests): credentials = ['project_admin', 'system_admin'] @decorators.idempotent_id('1fdbe493-e58f-48bf-bb38-52003eeef8cb') def test_get_capabilities(self): self._get_capabilities(expected_status=200)
deleted_lines: import abc from cinder_tempest_plugin.api.volume import baseclass VolumeV3RbacCapabilityTests(rbac_base.VolumeV3RbacBaseTests, metaclass=abc.ABCMeta): @classmethod def setup_credentials(cls): super().setup_credentials() cls.os_primary = getattr(cls, 'os_%s' % cls.credentials[0]) @abc.abstractmethod def test_get_capabilities(self): """Test volume_extension:capabilities policy. This test must check: * whether the persona can fetch capabilities for a host. """ pass class ProjectAdminTests(VolumeV3RbacCapabilityTests, base.BaseVolumeTest): credentials = ['project_admin', 'system_admin'] @decorators.idempotent_id('1fdbe493-e58f-48bf-bb38-52003eeef8cb') def test_get_capabilities(self): self.do_request('show_backend_capabilities', expected_status=200, host=host_name) class ProjectMemberTests(ProjectAdminTests, base.BaseVolumeTest): credentials = ['project_member', 'project_admin', 'system_admin'] @decorators.idempotent_id('dbaf51de-fafa-4f55-875f-7537524489ab') def test_get_capabilities(self): pools = self.admin_stats_client.list_pools()['pools'] host_name = pools[0]['name'] self.do_request('show_backend_capabilities', expected_status=exceptions.Forbidden, host=host_name) class ProjectReaderTests(ProjectMemberTests, base.BaseVolumeTest): super().test_get_capabilities()

Debug Nova APIs call failures

This should help finding out cause of failures happening
when performing API requests by reading the log file

commit_message:
OSC: Remove BGP calls to neutronclient

With [1] the python binding code in Neutronclient prints warning
about future deprecation, change neutron-dynamic-routing osc client
code to use totally OpenstackSDK.

[1]: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-neutronclient/+/862371

commit_message:
openstacksdk 1.1.0

version since this is the first release of the bobcat series.

commit_message:
Add Antelope support

* sync charm-helpers to classic charms
* change openstack-origin/source default to antelope
* align testing with antelope
* add new antelope bundles
* add antelope bundles to tests.yaml
* add antelope tests to osci.yaml and .zuul.yaml
* update build-on and run-on bases

Change-Id: I6ddab6f3b39a8f0fa4db07450022d85ba60d72de
(cherry picked from commit 6ad93e8710d1b1621d381c7b65ea5c91c0bd0906)

commit_message:
[nova] Add flag to set libvirt_tb_cache_size

A config option is being added in nova with [1]
in order to allow configuring lower tb-cache size
for qemu guest VMs.

This patch adds a flag in devstack so jobs can
utilize it to set required tb-cache size.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/868419

Related: blueprint libvirt-tb-cache-size
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/868419
Change-Id: Ifde737eb5d87dfe860445097d1f2b0ce16b0de05
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/80/881580/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # TB Cache Size in MiB for qemu guests NOVA_LIBVIRT_TB_CACHE_SIZE=${NOVA_LIBVIRT_TB_CACHE_SIZE:-0} if [ ${NOVA_LIBVIRT_TB_CACHE_SIZE} -gt 0 ]; then iniset $NOVA_CPU_CONF workarounds libvirt_tb_cache_size ${NOVA_LIBVIRT_TB_CACHE_SIZE} fi

commit_message:
Retire puppet-rally - Step 1: End project Gating

This module has not attracted any interest and has been unmaintained.
We asked any feedback[1] about retiring this module but have received
no objections so far, so we can assume no one is really using it.

[1] https://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2023-February/032245.html

Change-Id: Ib9ed3a2d263f7c8f998a0395b82f358f08bcfb1d

commit_message:
Add Yoga upgrade jobs

This patch aims to implement testing of SLURP upgrades. While
2023.1 is the first SLURP release, upgrade from Yoga to 2023.1 is
considered as unofficial SLURP upgrade.

With that we're adding changes to gate-check-commit to be able to
provide source release from which upgrade will be perfromed.

While running upgrade script user is required to provide source
release as input to script for SLURP releases.

Also regular upgrades are now switched to Zed as they supposed to be.

Change-Id: I64e55b2c685782d23bb84e7e9f7c60708c276cc3

commit_message:
linters: avoid broken ansible-compat

This avoids a broken release of ansible-compat per the linked bug
(assuming the next version will fix it, so optimistically not using
<), and is the same workaround we merged to the
openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs project in
https://review.opendev.org/881938 earlier today.

Change-Id: Ia43e8e481e34320bca2bed4a32b780f997c24c85

commit_message:
Stable artefacts for stable/2023.1 (antelope)

This patch is to lock the stable/2023.1 (antelope release) charms
down so that as much as possible.
In particular, this patch does:

- set the .gitreview to stable/2023.1
- lock zaza and zaza-openstack-tests to stable/antelope branches
- for reactive charms Add build.lock files to lock the layers
  and python modules used to build the charm.
- for ops framework charms, extract a pip freeze from the
  charmcraft container after building the charm to lock the
  modules used to build the charm.
- drop the kinetic bundles if the exist. (Note the updates to
  tests.yaml is in another batch (topic: antelope-voting)
- update the bundles so that they point to the antelope specific
  channels.  e.g. 2023.1/edge for OpenStack charms, 23.03/edge for
  OVN charms, quincy/edge for Ceph charms and generally, the
  appropriate LTS Jammy branch for the various support charms.

Change-Id: I9a307e2d6ac2d692f26d1b74d0b78dc994992f01

commit_message:
Enable jammy-antelope voting and drop kinetic-zed tests

* Voting was turned on for jammy-antelope in the
  project-template for charm-functional-jobs in zosci-config
* Voting for jammy-antelope bundles with non-standard names
  is turned on in individual charms
* Kinetic-zed bundles/tests are removed

Change-Id: I7ae50e72e6804e2ae7a5775f4d92642dfd93d537
(cherry picked from commit c3d460edbc215e09d59d47dd3481cdd36a3995fc)

commit_message:
Fix build

Add libpython3-dev to the list of the build-packages, this is needed
since https://github.com/juju-solutions/layer-basic/pull/214 .

'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2017-11-06 14:03:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/f9edf7adad1c00cedb7cd33268c06cc046aa8077', 'message': 'WIP: switch to use setuptools.scm

Quote from https://docs.openstack.org/pbr/latest/ with comments about
our usage:

  # it is True
  PBR can and does do a bunch of things for you:

    # it is a cool thing which is actually the main reason why we were
    # using PBR from the start
    Version: Manage version number based on git revisions and tags

    # we do not have such file
    AUTHORS: Generate AUTHORS file from git log

    # usually, commit message is oriented for being friendly for
    # rally-developers, not to end-users, so we need to write release
    # notes manually
    ChangeLog: Generate ChangeLog from git log

    # I do not know what is it
    Manifest: Generate a sensible manifest from git files and some
              standard files

    # we are using readthedocs for posting documentation and it doesn't
    # use this feature
    Sphinx Autodoc: Generate autodoc stub files for your whole module

    # simple open("requirements.txt").readlines()
    Requirements: Store your dependencies in a pip requirements file

    # simple open("requirements.txt").readlines()
    long_description: Use your README file as a long_description

    # it is actually not so smart, it includes redundant packages and
    # there is no way to specify what should be excluded
    Smart find_packages: Smartly find packages under your root package

PBR is a good lib which we were using for long time, but actually we
need just one feature from it - constructing the version from GIT.

Moving to setuptools-scm is not something very important and critical,
but it gives us several advantages:

* smaller libraries which provides less features should work quicker

* setuptools-scm is a lib from pypi team which is what the actual python
  world use and respect

* ability to specify which packages should be ignores.
  Explanation: We do not want to deliver our unit and functional tests,
               so 'tests' directory is located at the top level of our
               repository (not included into rally python package), BUT
               pbr smart package discovery includes this module into
               rally python package, so if you do `pip install rally` you
               will install both rally and tests. It is critical issue
               since other package can provide `tests` package and such
               conflict can not be fixes. It is true story and we had
               such issue with oauth2client (dependency of kubernetes).

* more control of how rally package is configured

Change-Id: Iadc75b3c88e5d924713f10e230aa982610dc1631

commit_message:
WIP: switch to use setuptools.scm

Quote from https://docs.openstack.org/pbr/latest/ with comments about
our usage:

  # it is True
  PBR can and does do a bunch of things for you:

    # it is a cool thing which is actually the main reason why we were
    # using PBR from the start
    Version: Manage version number based on git revisions and tags

    # we do not have such file
    AUTHORS: Generate AUTHORS file from git log

    # usually, commit message is oriented for being friendly for
    # rally-developers, not to end-users, so we need to write release
    # notes manually
    ChangeLog: Generate ChangeLog from git log

    # I do not know what is it
    Manifest: Generate a sensible manifest from git files and some
              standard files

    # we are using readthedocs for posting documentation and it doesn't
    # use this feature
    Sphinx Autodoc: Generate autodoc stub files for your whole module

    # simple open("requirements.txt").readlines()
    Requirements: Store your dependencies in a pip requirements file

    # simple open("requirements.txt").readlines()
    long_description: Use your README file as a long_description

    # it is actually not so smart, it includes redundant packages and
    # there is no way to specify what should be excluded
    Smart find_packages: Smartly find packages under your root package

PBR is a good lib which we were using for long time, but actually we
need just one feature from it - constructing the version from GIT.

Moving to setuptools-scm is not something very important and critical,
but it gives us several advantages:

* smaller libraries which provides less features should work quicker

* setuptools-scm is a lib from pypi team which is what the actual python
  world use and respect

* ability to specify which packages should be ignores.
  Explanation: We do not want to deliver our unit and functional tests,
               so 'tests' directory is located at the top level of our
               repository (not included into rally python package), BUT
               pbr smart package discovery includes this module into
               rally python package, so if you do `pip install rally` you
               will install both rally and tests. It is critical issue
               since other package can provide `tests` package and such
               conflict can not be fixes. It is true story and we had
               such issue with oauth2client (dependency of kubernetes).

* more control of how rally package is configured

commit_message:
Ensure service is restarted on unit file changes

At the moment we don't restart services if systemd unit file is changed.

We knowingly prevent systemd_service role handlers to execute
by providing `state: started` as otherwise service will be restarted twice.
With that now  we ensure that role handlers will also listen for systemd
unit changes.

Change-Id: I8ce4f18e853ee0c55970012f4c40574960607441

commit_message:
Ensure service is restarted on unit file changes

At the moment we don't restart services if systemd unit file is changed.

We knowingly prevent systemd_service role handlers to execute
by providing `state: started` as otherwise service will be restarted twice.
With that now  we ensure that role handlers will also listen for systemd
unit changes.

Change-Id: I5a52c0de14ee3a6215edb64dbc3bd48512d57e2e
Closes-Bug: #2009029

commit_message:
Remove creation of DHCP port in the OVN metadata unit test

It's not needed to create such port manually as it will be always
created by neutron when subnet is created.

Co-Authored-By: Rodolfo Alonso Hernandez <ralonsoh@redhat.com>

Trivial-Fix

Change-Id: I9499678fe244187977576cece101e28aa359a0d7

commit_message:
Fix functional tests modules which are using PluginFixture

Those modules needs to ensure that common config options
are registered.
Otherwise it can't be successfully run without other tests as it was
then failing due to unregistered config option.

Trivial-fix

Change-Id: I49b1ba8e7e455c701f983a80ca6ca1451e4bbd27

(core_plugin option especially) is registered.

unregistered config option.

commit_message:
Fix segments unit tests module

This module needs to ensure that common config options (service_plugins
option especially) is registered. Otherwise this test module can't be
successfully run without other tests as it was then failing due to
unregistered config option.

Trivial-fix

commit_message:
[S-RBAC] Get availability zone API available for READER role

API call get_availability_zone should be available in new policies for
all users with READER role as this is kind of the same what was in the
old policies (ANY).

Closes-bug: #2016266

Change-Id: I8a99bc52bd815fb3395e902fc8f85cf5f187e288

commit_message:
Drop py38 support from setup.cfg and tox.ini

The new supported runtimes for 2023.2 Bobcat [1] are py39 and py310.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/2023.2.html

Change-Id: Idb15e04c2e4176d6de45c182658a08099f0fb641

subject: Fix UTF-16 result handling for efibootmgr
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-04-27 15:57:06.000000000', 'files': ['ironic_python_agent/tests/unit/test_efi_utils.py', 'releasenotes/notes/fixes-efibootmgr-character-encoding-19e531ba694824c1.yaml', 'ironic_python_agent/efi_utils.py', 'ironic_python_agent/tests/unit/extensions/test_image.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent/commit/2fe6a4588c13e4b85a01ca4877203cd392b013e2', 'message': "Fix UTF-16 result handling for efibootmgr

The tl;dr is that UEFI NVRAM is in encoded
in UTF-16, and when we run the efibootmgr command,
we can get unicode characters back.

Except we previously were forcing everything to be
treated as UTF-8 due to the way oslo.concurrency's
processutils module works.

This could be observed with UTF character 0x00FF
which raises up a nice exception when we try to
decode it.

Anyhow! while fixing handling of this, we discovered
we could get basically the cruft out of the NVRAM,
by getting what was most likey a truncated string
out of our own test VMs. As such, we need to also
permit decoding to be tollerant of failures.
This could be binary data or as simple as flipped
bits which get interpretted invalid characters.
As such, we have introduced such data into one of our
tests involving UEFI record de-duplication.

Closes-Bug: 2015602
Change-Id: I006535bf124379ed65443c7b283bc99ecc95568b
(cherry picked from commit 76accfb880474445a5dcb07825889123b3dd0237)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix UTF-16 result handling for efibootmgr

The tl;dr is that UEFI NVRAM is in encoded
in UTF-16, and when we run the efibootmgr command,
we can get unicode characters back.

Except we previously were forcing everything to be
treated as UTF-8 due to the way oslo.concurrency's
processutils module works.

This could be observed with UTF character 0x00FF
which raises up a nice exception when we try to
decode it.

Anyhow! while fixing handling of this, we discovered
we could get basically the cruft out of the NVRAM,
by getting what was most likey a truncated string
out of our own test VMs. As such, we need to also
permit decoding to be tollerant of failures.
This could be binary data or as simple as flipped
bits which get interpretted invalid characters.
As such, we have introduced such data into one of our
tests involving UEFI record de-duplication.

Closes-Bug: 2015602
Change-Id: I006535bf124379ed65443c7b283bc99ecc95568b
(cherry picked from commit 76accfb880474445a5dcb07825889123b3dd0237)

commit_message:
Add support for interim Ubuntu releases

- update bundles to include UCA pocket tests
- update test configuration
- update metadata to include kinetic and lunar
- update snapcraft to allow run-on for kinetic and lunar

Change-Id: Ic4c19ccfc0ff42280634f5ba705c49ffb946799e

commit_message:
Fix exception in set-temp-url-secret action

There are two issues fixed in this bug. The first is that the
keystone_session exception block does not return on failure. The
second, and the reason that create_keystone_session is failing,
is due to the use of setuptools 60.9.0+ with the
importlib-metadata in wheelhouse.txt that is pinned to <3.0.0.
For more details see: https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/issues/3452

Closes-Bug: #2018018
Change-Id: I266c1fb92d531aded2f3253766de0a79accd9577
(cherry picked from commit 9f221f1087c51f9323dbb41cba52018a93ccce5e)

commit_message:
Release ironic for stable/xena

This release picks up new commits to ironic since
the last release from stable/xena.

This is being proposed as a convenience to help make sure stable
changes are being released. If the team is good with this going out,
please respond with a +1 to let the release team know it is OK to
proceed.

If it is not wanted at this time, or if there are more changes that
would be good to get merged before doing a stable release, please
leave a -1 with a comment with what the team would prefer. We can
then either abandon this patch, or wait for an update with a new
commit hash to use instead.

Signed-off-by: Herv Beraud <hberaud@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I3bb0d0416609562f234dd670ad58fef28dc1f99f

commit_message:
Fix UTF-16 result handling for efibootmgr

The tl;dr is that UEFI NVRAM is in encoded
in UTF-16, and when we run the efibootmgr command,
we can get unicode characters back.

Except we previously were forcing everything to be
treated as UTF-8 due to the way oslo.concurrency's
processutils module works.

This could be observed with UTF character 0x00FF
which raises up a nice exception when we try to
decode it.

Anyhow! while fixing handling of this, we discovered
we could get basically the cruft out of the NVRAM,
by getting what was most likey a truncated string
out of our own test VMs. As such, we need to also
permit decoding to be tollerant of failures.
This could be binary data or as simple as flipped
bits which get interpretted invalid characters.
As such, we have introduced such data into one of our
tests involving UEFI record de-duplication.

NOTE: One of the unit tests from the stable/xena backport
were removed, as software raid was still in-flight at the
end of Wallaby.

Closes-Bug: 2015602
Change-Id: I006535bf124379ed65443c7b283bc99ecc95568b
(cherry picked from commit 76accfb880474445a5dcb07825889123b3dd0237)
(cherry picked from commit 9f84c8b3d1fa0e08bf1f799f37a11698f8da07a4)
(cherry picked from commit d77424d7315e24390d6b159eab8dd9b3d4c56942)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent refs/changes/63/881763/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Invokes binary=True so we get a bytestream back. original_efi_output = utils.execute('efibootmgr', '-v', binary=True) # Bytes must be decoded before regex can be run and # matching to work as intended. # Also ignore errors on decoding, as we can basically get # garbage out of the nvram record, this way we don't fail # hard on unrelated records. original_efi_output = original_efi_output[0].decode( 'utf-16', errors='ignore') for line in original_efi_output.split('\n'):
deleted_lines: original_efi_output = utils.execute('efibootmgr', '-v') for line in original_efi_output[0].split('\n'):

commit_message:
Fix UTF-16 result handling for efibootmgr

The tl;dr is that UEFI NVRAM is in encoded
in UTF-16, and when we run the efibootmgr command,
we can get unicode characters back.

Except we previously were forcing everything to be
treated as UTF-8 due to the way oslo.concurrency's
processutils module works.

This could be observed with UTF character 0x00FF
which raises up a nice exception when we try to
decode it.

Anyhow! while fixing handling of this, we discovered
we could get basically the cruft out of the NVRAM,
by getting what was most likey a truncated string
out of our own test VMs. As such, we need to also
permit decoding to be tollerant of failures.
This could be binary data or as simple as flipped
bits which get interpretted invalid characters.
As such, we have introduced such data into one of our
tests involving UEFI record de-duplication.

Closes-Bug: 2015602
Change-Id: I006535bf124379ed65443c7b283bc99ecc95568b
(cherry picked from commit 76accfb880474445a5dcb07825889123b3dd0237)

commit_message:
Fix UTF-16 result handling for efibootmgr

The tl;dr is that UEFI NVRAM is in encoded
in UTF-16, and when we run the efibootmgr command,
we can get unicode characters back.

Except we previously were forcing everything to be
treated as UTF-8 due to the way oslo.concurrency's
processutils module works.

This could be observed with UTF character 0x00FF
which raises up a nice exception when we try to
decode it.

Anyhow! while fixing handling of this, we discovered
we could get basically the cruft out of the NVRAM,
by getting what was most likey a truncated string
out of our own test VMs. As such, we need to also
permit decoding to be tollerant of failures.
This could be binary data or as simple as flipped
bits which get interpretted invalid characters.
As such, we have introduced such data into one of our
tests involving UEFI record de-duplication.

Closes-Bug: 2015602
Change-Id: I006535bf124379ed65443c7b283bc99ecc95568b
(cherry picked from commit 76accfb880474445a5dcb07825889123b3dd0237)

commit_message:
Disable MD5 image checksums

MD5 image checksums have long been supersceeded by the use of a
``os_hash_algo`` and ``os_hash_value`` field as part of the
properties of an image.

In the process of doing this, we determined that checksum via
URL usage was non-trivial and determined that an appropriate
path was to allow the checksum type to be determined as needed.

Change-Id: I26ba8f8c37d663096f558e83028ff463d31bd4e6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent refs/changes/90/865190/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not CONF.md5_enabled: raise ValueError('MD5 support is disabled.') if CONF.md5_enabled: md5sum_avail = True

commit_message:
Support create profile with subnet

This patch allow to define subnet in profile,
Default network port will find a random subnet to create port on, user can define specific subnet.

Change-Id: I8a29dcb7c8b92c8bd1b8c9111134c3ace6ea9a76

commit_message:
Fix exception in set-temp-url-secret action

There are two issues fixed in this bug. The first is that the
keystone_session exception block does not return on failure. The
second, and the reason that create_keystone_session is failing,
is due to the use of setuptools 60.9.0+ with the
importlib-metadata in wheelhouse.txt that is pinned to <3.0.0.
For more details see: https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/issues/3452

Closes-Bug: #2018018
Change-Id: I266c1fb92d531aded2f3253766de0a79accd9577
(cherry picked from commit 9f221f1087c51f9323dbb41cba52018a93ccce5e)

commit_message:
flake8 : ignore .cache subdirectory, avoid broken ansible-compat

This role pulls in zuul-jobs/system-config, etc. for roles into
.cache.  We don't want to flake8 them as part of this job; ignore the
.cache subdir.

This also avoids a broken release of ansible-compat per the linked bug
(I'm assuming the next version will fix it, so optimistically not
using <)

Change-Id: I5cf3029e40fcc0e02ba4d104beb59a1c75509a77

commit_message:
Add job to ansible-config_template to Galaxy

At the moment secret that is being used to access Ansible Galaxy
`openstack` namespace is stored in `ansible-collections-openstack` [1]

The only way to leverage this secret for other project to publish it in
the same  namespace is to add job with secret inside the trusted project

Another approach of fully moving the job to the trusted repo was
declined [2]

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/ansible-collections-openstack/src/branch/master/.zuul.yaml#L285-L306
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/project-config/+/850664

Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ansible-config_template/+/881929
Change-Id: I082d8c53d099dbde4494cca31c5134805a7eeb9f

commit_message:
Use release-ansible-collections from project-config

Since secrets are unique per project, it's not possible jsut to re-use
job from ansible-collections-openstack. So we define individual api key
per repo and parenting same job that is stored in project-config.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/project-config/+/850664
Change-Id: If50daae8d46dffb5e7e7742feaa88eb0be7aa699

subject: Add job for publishing ansible collections
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-07-21 14:55:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/80618ecfc6d2e943904b28c5f1f7af176a4eac33', 'message': 'Add job for publishing ansible collections

With this commit we add "base" job for publishing ansible collections to
ansible galaxy. However, in order to use it, each project must have
`ansible_galaxy_info` secret defined, where access to galaxy is stored.
It's done this way so that projects could use different namespaces for
publlishing and they could be defined as childs to this job.

Change-Id: I71480ed2a40802176c6299484475cbf1e0727fdc
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2022-07-21 15:16:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/7748dcece242111b5cbb412333f06a7f2e6bea7f', 'message': 'Add job for publishing ansible collections

With this commit we add "base" job for publishing ansible collections to
ansible galaxy. However, in order to use it, each project must have
`ansible_galaxy_info` secret defined, where access to galaxy is stored.
It's done this way so that projects could use different namespaces for

commit_message:
Add job for publishing ansible collections

With this commit we add "base" job for publishing ansible collections to
ansible galaxy. However, in order to use it, each project must have
`ansible_galaxy_info` secret defined, where access to galaxy is stored.
It's done this way so that projects could use different namespaces for
publlishing and they could be defined as childs to this job.

Change-Id: I71480ed2a40802176c6299484475cbf1e0727fdc

Secret must contain `token` for accessing galaxy and can contain `url` key to override default ansible-galaxy URL. run: playbooks/ansible-collections/run.yml - job:

commit_message:
Add TLS support to repo_server backends

By overriding the variable `repo_backend_ssl: True` HTTPS will
be enabled, disabling HTTP support on the repo_server backend.

The ansible-role-pki is used to generate the required TLS
certificates if this functionality is enabled.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible/+/879085
Change-Id: I5c5d3dd5689ac122781303ad21dacc8a1fa746eb

added_lines: ### ### Backend TLS ### # Define if communication between haproxy and service backends should be # encrypted with TLS. repo_backend_https: "{{ openstack_backend_service_https | default(False) }}" # Storage location for SSL certificate authority repo_pki_dir: "{{ openstack_pki_dir }}" # Delegated host for operating the certificate authority repo_pki_setup_host: "{{ openstack_pki_setup_host | default('localhost') }}" # The local address used for the repo node repo_node_address: "{{ management_address | default('127.0.0.1') }}" # repo server certificate repo_pki_keys_path: "{{ repo_pki_dir ~ '/certs/private/' }}" repo_pki_certs_path: "{{ repo_pki_dir ~ '/certs/certs/' }}" repo_pki_intermediate_cert_name: "{{ openstack_pki_service_intermediate_cert_name }}" repo_pki_intermediate_cert_path: "{{ repo_pki_dir ~ '/roots/' ~ repo_pki_intermediate_cert_name ~ '/certs/' ~ repo_pki_intermediate_cert_name ~ '.crt' }}" repo_pki_regen_cert: '' repo_pki_certificates: - name: "repo_{{ ansible_facts['hostname'] }}" provider: ownca cn: "{{ ansible_facts['hostname'] }}" san: "{{ 'DNS:' ~ ansible_facts['hostname'] ~ ',IP:' ~ repo_node_address }}" signed_by: "{{ repo_pki_intermediate_cert_name }}" # repo destination files for SSL certificates repo_ssl_cert: /etc/repo/repo.pem repo_ssl_key: /etc/repo/repo.key repo_ssl_ca_cert: /etc/ssl/certs/repo-ca.pem # Define when CA shoud be used repo_ssl_use_ca: "{{ repo_backend_https | bool or repo_user_ssl_ca_cert is defined }}" # Installation details for SSL certificates repo_pki_install_certificates: - src: "{{ repo_user_ssl_cert | default(repo_pki_certs_path ~ 'repo_' ~ ansible_facts['hostname'] ~ '-chain.crt') }}" dest: "{{ repo_ssl_cert }}" owner: "{{ repo_service_user_name }}" group: "{{ repo_service_group_name }}" mode: "0644" - src: "{{ repo_user_ssl_key | default(repo_pki_keys_path ~ 'repo_' ~ ansible_facts['hostname'] ~ '.key.pem') }}" dest: "{{ repo_ssl_key }}" owner: "{{ repo_service_user_name }}" group: "{{ repo_service_group_name }}" mode: "0600" - src: "{{ repo_user_ssl_ca_cert | default(repo_pki_intermediate_cert_path) }}" dest: "{{ repo_ssl_ca_cert }}" owner: "{{ repo_service_user_name }}" group: "{{ repo_service_group_name }}" mode: "0644" condition: "{{ repo_ssl_use_ca }}" # Define user-provided SSL certificates #repo_user_ssl_cert: <path to cert on ansible deployment host> #repo_user_ssl_key: <path to cert on ansible deployment host> #repo_user_ssl_ca_cert: <path to cert on ansible deployment host>

commit_message:
[WIP] Add share server resource to shared file system

Change-Id: I7c9216c372efe767cb9f08eafb395b0d845903fb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk refs/changes/99/881899/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import json share_group_type as _share_group_type ) from openstack.shared_file_system.v2 import (from openstack.shared_file_system.v2 import share_type as _share_type from openstack.shared_file_system.v2 import share_server as _share_server "share_type": _share_type.ShareType, "share_group_type": _share_group_type.ShareGroupType, "share_server": _share_server.ShareServer, def share_types(self, **query): """List shared file system share types :param kwargs query: Optional query parameters to be sent to limit the share types being returned. Available parameters include: * extra_specs: The extra specifications as a set of one or more key-value pairs. * is_public: A boolean query parameter that, when set to true, allows retrieving public resources that belong to all projects. :returns: A generator of share type resources :rtype: :class:`~openstack.shared_file_system.v2. share_type.ShareType` """ if 'extra_specs' in query: query['extra_specs'] = json.dumps(query['extra_specs']) return self._list( _share_type.ShareType, **query) def get_share_type(self, share_type_id): """List details of a single share type :param share_type_id: The ID of the share type :returns: Details of identified share type :rtype: :class:`~openstack.shared_file_system.v2. share_type.ShareType` """ return self._get(_share_type.ShareType, share_type_id) def delete_share_type(self, share_type_id, ignore_missing=True): """Deletes a single share type :param share: The ID of the share type :returns: ``None`` """ self._delete( _share_type.ShareType, share_type_id, ignore_missing=ignore_missing) def update_share_type(self, share_type_id, **attrs): """Updates details of a single share type :param share_type_id: The ID of the share type to update. :param dict attrs: The attributes to update on the share type :returns: Updated details of the identified share type :rtype: :class:`~openstack.shared_file_system.v2. share_type.ShareType` """ return self._update( _share_type.ShareType, share_type_id, **attrs) def update_share_type_extra_specs(self, share_type_id, **attrs): """Update the extra_specs for a type. :param share_type_id: The ID of the share type. :param dict attrs: The extra_spec attributes to update on the type represented by ``value``. :returns: A dict containing updated extra_specs """ res = self._get_resource(_share_type.ShareType, share_type_id) extra_specs = res.set_extra_specs(self, **attrs) result = _share_type.ShareType.existing( id=res.id, extra_specs=extra_specs) return result def delete_share_type_extra_specs(self, share_type_id, keys): """Delete the extra_specs for a share type Note: This method will do a HTTP DELETE request for each key in keys. :param share_type_id: The ID of the share type. :param keys: The keys to delete :returns: ``None`` """ res = self._get_resource(_share_type.ShareType, share_type_id) return res.delete_extra_specs(self, keys) def create_share_type(self, name, dhss, **attrs): """Creates a share from attributes :returns: Details of the new share type :param name: Name of the new share type :param dhss: Boolean value of driver handles share servers flag :param dict attrs: Attributes which will be used to create a :class:`~openstack.shared_file_system.v2. share_type.ShareType`,comprised of the properties on the Share types class. Currently "description" and "extra_specs" are allowed attributes. :rtype: :class:`~openstack.shared_file_system.v2. share_type.ShareType` """ attrs['name'] = name extra_specs = attrs.pop('extra_specs', {}) extra_specs.pop('driver_handles_share_servers', None) extra_specs.update({ 'driver_handles_share_servers': dhss, }) attrs['extra_specs'] = extra_specs return self._create(_share_type.ShareType, **attrs) def share_group_types(self, **query): """List shared file system share group types :param kwargs query: Optional query parameters to be sent to limit the share types being returned. Available parameters include: * group_specs: The extra specifications as a set of one or more key-value pairs. * share_types: Associated ShareTypes as a list of ShareType ids. * is_public: A boolean query parameter that, when set to true, allows retrieving public resources that belong to all projects. """ if 'group_specs' in query: query['group_specs'] = json.dumps(query['group_specs']) if 'share_types' in query: query['share_types'] = json.dumps(query['share_types']) return self._list( _share_group_type.ShareGroupType, **query) def get_share_group_type(self, share_group_type_id): """List details of a single share group type :param share_group_type_id: The ID of the share group type :returns: Details of identified share group type :rtype: :class:`~openstack.shared_file_system.v2. share_group_type.ShareGroupType` """ return self._get(_share_group_type.ShareGroupType, share_group_type_id) def delete_share_group_type(self, share_group_type_id, ignore_missing=True): """Deletes a single share group type :param share: The ID of the share group type :returns: ``None`` """ self._delete( _share_group_type.ShareGroupType, share_group_type_id, ignore_missing=ignore_missing) def update_share_group_type(self, share_group_type_id, **attrs): """Updates details of a single share group type :param share_group_type_id: The ID of the share group type to update. :param dict attrs: The attributes to update on the share group type :returns: Updated details of the identified share group type :rtype: :class:`~openstack.shared_file_system.v2. share_group_type.ShareGroupType` """ return self._update( _share_group_type.ShareGroupType, share_group_type_id, **attrs) def create_share_group_type(self, name, **attrs): """Creates a share group type from attributes :returns: Details of the new share group type :param name: Name of the new share group type :param dict attrs: Attributes which will be used to create a :class:`~openstack.shared_file_system.v2. share_group_type.ShareGroupType`,comprised of the properties on the Share group types class. Currently "group_specs" and "share_types" are allowed attributes. :rtype: :class:`~openstack.shared_file_system.v2. share_group_type.ShareGroupType` """ attrs['name'] = name return self._create(_share_group_type.ShareGroupType, **attrs) def share_servers(self, **query): """Lists all share servers. :param kwargs query: Optional query parameters to be sent to limit the share servers being returned. :returns: A generator of manila share servers resources :rtype: :class:`~openstack.shared_file_system.v2. share_server.Limit` """ return self._list( _share_server.ShareServer, **query)

commit_message:
workaround: requests verify handling if env is set

if the env REQUESTS_CA_BUNDLE is set the requests.Session() ignores the
verify parameter. Therefore the verify parameter is moved directly into
the function call of request.

Workaround for https://github.com/psf/requests/issues/3829

Change-Id: I66dc7c4d90e5bd5e3d1b331cf1728f27dece6dd4
(cherry picked from commit 98c899997f4f7b7aaccf911c41655aad6548fe6c)

subject: [functional] Fix db_set use in test_cascading_del_in_txn
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-04-29 07:11:38.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/tests/functional/agent/test_ovs_lib.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/2be53b1719e24d9a5be42505386a72ccdb26ef8f', 'message': "[functional] Fix db_set use in test_cascading_del_in_txn

With ovsdbapp-2.3.0 release 'db_set' method excepts
if_exists(defaults to True) option.

The default behavior made the test to fail
as it was expecting transaction to fail.
Adding if_exists=False so it persists the
old behavior.

Closes-Bug: #2018130
Change-Id: I3dfdb0cce89cb860991a731b9a03313402956ddf
"}]
commit_message:
[functional] Fix db_set use in test_cascading_del_in_txn

With ovsdbapp-2.3.0 release 'db_set' method excepts
if_exists(defaults to True) option.

The default behavior made the test to fail
as it was expecting transaction to fail.
Adding if_exists=False so it persists the
old behavior.

Closes-Bug: #2018130
Change-Id: I3dfdb0cce89cb860991a731b9a03313402956ddf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/96/881896/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
formpost: optionally specify a digest for form_signature

Give the formpost signature an argparse overhaul so we can optionally
pass in a digest to use.

This makes the tool more useful, eventually this form generation will move
into the swiftclient, I have already provided a patch [0]

[0] - https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-swiftclient/+/833954

Change-Id: I6b4fe772405f6c02d0dcd3b5569ba8b56e4528df

added_lines: from hashlib import sha256, sha512 max_file_size = int(1024 * 1024 * 1024 * 3.14159) #  GiB max_file_count = 3 path, redirect, str(max_file_size), str(max_file_count), out = six.StringIO() with mock.patch('swift.cli.form_signature.time', lambda: the_time): with mock.patch('sys.stdout', out): exitcode = form_signature.main([ path, redirect, str(max_file_size), str(max_file_count), str(expires), key]) expected_signature = hmac.new(key, data, sha512).hexdigest() self.assertEqual(exitcode, 0) self.assertIn("Signature: sha512:%s" % expected_signature, out.getvalue()) self.assertIn("Expires: %d" % (the_time + expires,), out.getvalue()) sig_input = ( '<input type="hidden" name="signature" value="sha512:%s" />' % expected_signature) self.assertIn(sig_input, out.getvalue()) def test_prints_signature_different_algorithm(self): the_time = 1406143563.020043 key = 'secret squirrel' expires = 3600 path = '/v1/a/c/o' redirect = 'https://example.com/done.html' max_file_size = int(1024 * 1024 * 1024 * 3.14159) #  GiB max_file_count = 3 data = "\n".join(( path, redirect, str(max_file_size), str(max_file_count), str(int(the_time + expires)))) '--algorithm', 'sha256', path, redirect, str(max_file_size), str(max_file_count), str(expires), key]) if six.PY3: data = data if isinstance(data, six.binary_type) else \ data.encode('utf8') key = key if isinstance(key, six.binary_type) else \ key.encode('utf8') expected_signature = hmac.new(key, data, sha256).hexdigest() self.assertIn("Signature: sha256:%s" % expected_signature, sig_input = ( '<input type="hidden" name="signature" value="sha256:%s" />' % expected_signature) with mock.patch('sys.stderr', out),\ self.assertRaises(SystemExit): form_signature.main([ if six.PY2: expected = 'error: too few arguments' else: expected = 'the following arguments are required: key' self.assertIn(expected, out.getvalue())

commit_message:
Ensure service_users_to_delete is not None and old_service_users is a str

Event `remove-secret` can fail if `old_service_users` is None. Moreover,
`set_app_data` will fail if the value type is not `str`.

Change-Id: I0deb9f0689cccba884ffa520a2f2cb114f47a6d1

subject: openstack/release : return to non-blocking submit rule
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-03-16 22:44:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/c056641f63e2e508182c75415cf5e9337f9bace5', 'message': 'openstack/release : return to non-blocking submit rule

The PTL-Approval vote is added by Zuul, which looks at who has voted
and compares it to the PTL lists, and marks it with +1 if the project
PTL has seen it.

It doesn't really have a -1 state; this was added with
Idbf614be4b88db56258ed3b0e7725b581196a6fb to try and get the column to
appear.

As discussed in [1] I don't believe this is the cause of the missing
column.  Basically the column will only show up if there is a
*blocking* vote -- the assumption is I guess that if the change
doesn't have something stopping it merging, then it's not really
relevant for the overview.

This is a regression from 3.5 -- there *any* vote would make the
column appear.

I think the thread [1] explains it -- to be frank I'm not sure we have
a good answer.  The UI is very focused around this idea of
blocking/non-blocking votes, rather than "informational" things like
PTL-Approval.

But with this now being a submit-requirement of !=-1, the UI is even
*more* confusing because the PTL-Approval label *always* looks like it
is valid.  Since 0/+1 are both satisfying the sr, it gets a green
circle tick on the overview page.  I think that by removing this, we
at least won't show that in the UI, even though the original problem
isn't really solved.

[1] https://groups.google.com/g/repo-discuss/c/gYVD-iBR9Ow/m/p_i5L4_vAQAJ

Change-Id: Idba8dcd1b1ee3a0865e785e220eef22f8c8f213d

commit_message:
openstack/release : return to non-blocking submit rule

The PTL-Approval vote is added by Zuul, which looks at who has voted
and compares it to the PTL lists, and marks it with +1 if the project
PTL has seen it.

It doesn't really have a -1 state; this was added with
Idbf614be4b88db56258ed3b0e7725b581196a6fb to try and get the column to
appear.

As discussed in [1] I don't believe this is the cause of the missing
column.  Basically the column will only show up if there is a
*blocking* vote -- the assumption is I guess that if the change
doesn't have something stopping it merging, then it's not really
relevant for the overview.

This is a regression from 3.5 -- there *any* vote would make the
column appear.

I think the thread [1] explains it -- to be frank I'm not sure we have
a good answer.  The UI is very focused around this idea of
blocking/non-blocking votes, rather than "informational" things like
PTL-Approval.

But with this now being a submit-requirement of !=-1, the UI is even
*more* confusing because the PTL-Approval label *always* looks like it
is valid.  Since 0/+1 are both satisfying the sr, it gets a green
circle tick on the overview page.  I think that by removing this, we
at least won't show that in the UI, even though the original problem
isn't really solved.

[1] https://groups.google.com/g/repo-discuss/c/gYVD-iBR9Ow/m/p_i5L4_vAQAJ

Change-Id: Idba8dcd1b1ee3a0865e785e220eef22f8c8f213d

commit_message:
Update v3_endpoint_type to use public

The default endpoint type for OpenStack Identity should be the public
version, and it was something missed for a while.

Change-Id: Ib679fb21d8d815317ecdd03e40dfe16e6ef3915e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/25/881825/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: default='public',

subject: [ovn] Drop use of LR OVN_GW_NETWORK_EXT_ID_KEY
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-03-16 19:24:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/bdb1e53d34cac9aa06109ba62da330bc35e54a10', 'message': 'WIP [ovn] Drop use of LR OVN_GW_NETWORK_EXT_ID_KEY

An update to the OVN QoS driver to support the `qos_gateway_ip`
QoS extension [0] introduced adding the GW network id as an
external_id on the Logical_Router (LR).  This is problematic
when introducing multiple gateway ports, because a single LR
can have gateways in multiple networks.

The external_id key was presumably added because at the point in
time when a LR is deleted, the code had no other source of this
information.  However, it turns out this step is redundant and
not neccessary.

To prove this I include a excerpt of a stack trace when deleting
a router in the commit message:

    File "services/ovn_l3/plugin.py", line 210, in delete_router
      super(OVNL3RouterPlugin, self).delete_router(context, id)
    File "db/l3_db.py", line 612, in delete_router
      self._delete_current_gw_port(context, id, router, None)
    File "db/l3_db.py", line 452, in _delete_current_gw_port
      self._core_plugin.delete_port(
    File "plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/mech_driver.py",
        line 886, in delete_port_postcommit
      self._ovn_client.delete_port(context.plugin_context, port['id'],
    File "plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/ovn_client.py",
        line 830, in delete_port
      self._delete_port(port_id, port_object=port_object)

Essentially, a routers GW port(s) will be removed prior to
deleting the router itself.

The `ovn_client.delete_port` method will call on the QoS extension
to remove rules matching the GW port, and that will be the same
rules as has previously been added for the router.

I also added a functional test that confirms this fact [1].

'}, {'number': 10, 'created': '2023-03-29 17:58:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/5b41204df54387420c8432aaf2f1263416fc5378', 'message': '[ovn] Drop use of LR OVN_GW_NETWORK_EXT_ID_KEY

An update to the OVN QoS driver to support the `qos_gateway_ip`
QoS extension [0] introduced adding the GW network id as an
external_id on the Logical_Router (LR).  This is problematic
when introducing multiple gateway ports, because a single LR
can have gateways in multiple networks.

The external_id key was presumably added because at the point in
time when a LR is deleted, the code had no other source of this
information.  However, it turns out this step is redundant and
not neccessary.

To prove this I include a excerpt of a stack trace when deleting
a router in the commit message:

    File "services/ovn_l3/plugin.py", line 210, in delete_router
      super(OVNL3RouterPlugin, self).delete_router(context, id)
    File "db/l3_db.py", line 612, in delete_router
      self._delete_current_gw_port(context, id, router, None)
    File "db/l3_db.py", line 452, in _delete_current_gw_port
      self._core_plugin.delete_port(
    File "plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/mech_driver.py",
        line 886, in delete_port_postcommit
      self._ovn_client.delete_port(context.plugin_context, port['id'],
    File "plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/ovn_client.py",
        line 830, in delete_port
      self._delete_port(port_id, port_object=port_object)

Essentially, a routers GW port(s) will be removed prior to
deleting the router itself.

The `ovn_client.delete_port` method will call on the QoS extension
to remove rules matching the GW port, and that will be the same
rules as has previously been added for the router.

I also added a functional test that confirms this fact [1].

commit_message:
[ovn] Drop use of LR OVN_GW_NETWORK_EXT_ID_KEY

An update to the OVN QoS driver to support the `qos_gateway_ip`
QoS extension [0] introduced adding the GW network id as an
external_id on the Logical_Router (LR).  This is problematic
when introducing multiple gateway ports, because a single LR
can have gateways in multiple networks.

The external_id key was presumably added because at the point in
time when a LR is deleted, the code had no other source of this
information.  However, it turns out this step is redundant and
not neccessary.

To prove this I include a excerpt of a stack trace when deleting
a router in the commit message:

    File "services/ovn_l3/plugin.py", line 210, in delete_router
      super(OVNL3RouterPlugin, self).delete_router(context, id)
    File "db/l3_db.py", line 612, in delete_router
      self._delete_current_gw_port(context, id, router, None)
    File "db/l3_db.py", line 452, in _delete_current_gw_port
      self._core_plugin.delete_port(
    File "plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/mech_driver.py",
        line 886, in delete_port_postcommit
      self._ovn_client.delete_port(context.plugin_context, port['id'],
    File "plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/ovn_client.py",
        line 830, in delete_port
      self._delete_port(port_id, port_object=port_object)

Essentially, a routers GW port(s) will be removed prior to
deleting the router itself.

The `ovn_client.delete_port` method will call on the QoS extension
to remove rules matching the GW port, and that will be the same
rules as has previously been added for the router.

I also added a functional test that confirms this fact [1].

commit_message:
Fix exception in set-temp-url-secret action

There are two issues fixed in this bug. The first is that the
keystone_session exception block does not return on failure. The
second, and the reason that create_keystone_session is failing,
is due to the use of setuptools 60.9.0+ with the
importlib-metadata in wheelhouse.txt that is pinned to <3.0.0.
For more details see: https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/issues/3452

Closes-Bug: #2018018
Change-Id: I266c1fb92d531aded2f3253766de0a79accd9577

commit_message:
Create octavia multi-vCPU flavor

Creates a new Nova flavor, an Octavia flavorprofile and a Octavia flavor
that can be used for creating loadbalancers.
This can boost the network throughput when using Amphorae with
multiple vCPUs.

Depends-on: Id6b31143939067327011c346b3f1361902acabcf
Change-Id: I925a0403899aff881816c4903998e369acfab71f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible refs/changes/58/879258/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: create nova multi-vCPU flavor for Octavia shell: | if ! openstack flavor show octavia_{{ octavia_multivcpu_flavor_properties.nova_flavor_id }} > /dev/null; then openstack flavor create -vv \ --id {{ octavia_multivcpu_flavor_properties.nova_flavor_id }} \ --ram {{ octavia_multivcpu_flavor_properties.ram }} \ --disk {{ octavia_multivcpu_flavor_properties.disk }} \ --vcpus {{ octavia_multivcpu_flavor_properties.vcpus }} \ --private \ octavia_{{ octavia_multivcpu_flavor_properties.nova_flavor_id }} fi run_once: true when: octavia_manage_nova_flavor | default(false) | bool - name: create octavia multi-vCPU flavor profile shell: | if ! openstack loadbalancer flavorprofile show {{ octavia_multivcpu_flavor_properties.flavorprofile_name }} > /dev/null; then openstack loadbalancer flavorprofile create -vv \ --name {{ octavia_multivcpu_flavor_properties.flavorprofile_name }} \ --provider amphora --flavor-data \ '{"loadbalancer_topology": "ACTIVE_STANDBY", "compute_flavor": "{{ octavia_multivcpu_flavor_properties.nova_flavor_id }}"}' fi run_once: true when: octavia_manage_nova_flavor | default(false) | bool - name: create octavia multi-vCPU flavor shell: | if ! openstack loadbalancer flavor show {{ octavia_multivcpu_flavor_properties.flavor_name }} > /dev/null; then openstack loadbalancer flavor create -vv \ --name {{ octavia_multivcpu_flavor_properties.flavor_name }} \ --flavorprofile {{ octavia_multivcpu_flavor_properties.flavorprofile_name }} \ --description "A flavor with {{ octavia_multivcpu_flavor_properties.vcpus }} \ vCPUs and {{ octavia_multivcpu_flavor_properties.ram }} MB RAM." fi run_once: true when: octavia_manage_nova_flavor | default(false) | bool

subject: Prevent incorrect reschedule of resumed tasks with jobboard
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-04-07 09:26:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/octavia/commit/514fa234a55d602d91c81f24a24cb8c570afe1a5', 'message': 'Prevent incorrect reschedule of resumed tasks with jobboard

A previous patch [0] introduced a keepalive mechanism that allows a
controller to notify taskflow that a task is being executed.
But it doesn't handle "resumed" tasks (tasks that have been rescheduled
from one controller to another controller).

This patch moves this keepalive task in a thread that is attached to a
taskflow conductor, the thread will extend the expiration of the tasks
that are executed by this conductor.

[0] I6619ba117f7051fe44086389789bc6e2810fd23d

Story 2009998
Task 45089

Conflicts:
	octavia/tests/unit/common/test_base_taskflow.py

Change-Id: I29fcad9e121a30d6e8f8178f2f078cf10771a32a

commit_message:
Prevent incorrect reschedule of resumed tasks with jobboard

A previous patch [0] introduced a keepalive mechanism that allows a
controller to notify taskflow that a task is being executed.
But it doesn't handle "resumed" tasks (tasks that have been rescheduled
from one controller to another controller).

This patch moves this keepalive task in a thread that is attached to a
taskflow conductor, the thread will extend the expiration of the tasks
that are executed by this conductor.

[0] I6619ba117f7051fe44086389789bc6e2810fd23d

Story 2009998
Task 45089

Conflicts:
	octavia/tests/unit/common/test_base_taskflow.py

Change-Id: I29fcad9e121a30d6e8f8178f2f078cf10771a32a
(cherry picked from commit d367b47639af02aaaff80cd62629f5c8e7f3f91a)
(cherry picked from commit 0d5bcb296352d37307978a8b0550a50b80402024)
(cherry picked from commit 705503ee11278989bd80baef04a77fca587dfde2)

commit_message:
Stop gathering local software_versions for services

With latest ansible-core playbooks started failing on adding extra compute
or controller nodes, when cinder/nova playbooks run with limits.

This happens as we're trying to reply on local facts for hosts that are
expired. At the same time, it's not always possible to collect them, as some computes
can be down while adding another one.

With that we're simplifying flow and avoid old process of
restarting services or executing migrations based on local facts.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_nova/+/880147
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_cinder/+/880210
Closes-Bug: #2009834
Change-Id: I44dc8567e9a93f91327202de1bf88a067266711d

commit_message:
Remove nomodeset from usage

In investigating packet loss issues, it was discovered that the
root cause to the packet loss issues were the graphical updates
on the console from logging, or other activites such as
interacting with the system console.

In particular, this was discovered to be the case with embedded
graphics controllers which are also in with onboard graphics in
physical servers.

i.e. A server using an aspeed/matrox VGA graphics controller
would be affected, whereas the same server using an add-in GPU
would not experience the same issue.

The root cause, in itself is the use of the ``nomodeset`` option
which is intended more for troubleshooting and provides
framebuffer memory, which results in the NUMA node being locked
upon updates creating the expeienced latency/packet loss
depending on the specific conditions of the machine.

Resolves: rhbz#2179366
Change-Id: I27228ac65000c1a1f17925a3bcc82adffe518c10

subject: Don't monkey patch logging on import
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-17 01:48:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/e0f4db2627bf85f3cc13cc4be605a799ba3fe3a6', 'message': 'swift.common.utils no longer monkey patches logging upon import.

Previously swift.common.utils monkey patched logging.thread,
logging.threading, and logging._lock upon import with eventlet
threading modules. This puts the monkey patch inside wrapper
"patch_logging" which is called at the beginning of get_logger.

Change-Id: I6f35ad41414898fb7dc5da422f524eb52ff2940f
Closes-Bug: #1380815
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2022-04-08 19:25:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/d3267fd7c5508f536624ebc2935abec32032fc01', 'message': 'swift.common.utils no longer monkey patches logging upon import.

Previously swift.common.utils monkey patched logging.thread,
logging.threading, and logging._lock upon import with eventlet
threading modules, but that is no longer reasonable or necessary.

Change-Id: I6f35ad41414898fb7dc5da422f524eb52ff2940f
Closes-Bug: #1380815
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2022-04-13 19:24:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/e2b2a2c3062fa78236bdda868542b8b9923e726c', 'message': "Don't monkey patch logging on import

Previously swift.common.utils monkey patched logging.thread,
logging.threading, and logging._lock upon import with eventlet
threading modules, but that is no longer reasonable or necessary.

Instead we can let eventlet.moneky_patch(thread) green existing
threading locks created using gc consistently across WSGI apps and our
daemons.

Co-Authored-By: Clay Gerrard <clay.gerrard@gmail.com>
Closes-Bug: #1380815
Change-Id: I6f35ad41414898fb7dc5da422f524eb52ff2940f
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2022-05-02 19:43:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/d09faee2627ad689c223d7142c806211fdd22af0', 'message': "Don't monkey patch logging on import

Previously swift.common.utils monkey patched logging.thread,
logging.threading, and logging._lock upon import with eventlet
threading modules, but that is no longer reasonable or necessary.

Instead we group all monkey patching into utils function and apply
patching consistently across daemons and WSGI servers.

Co-Authored-By: Clay Gerrard <clay.gerrard@gmail.com>
Closes-Bug: #1380815
Change-Id: I6f35ad41414898fb7dc5da422f524eb52ff2940f
"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2022-09-21 19:26:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/8c083ee8ba6d26c1267387a00344de236ee6d59f', 'message': "Don't monkey patch logging on import

Previously swift.common.utils monkey patched logging.thread,
logging.threading, and logging._lock upon import with eventlet
threading modules, but that is no longer reasonable or necessary.

With py3, the existing logging._lock is not patched by eventlet,
unless the logging module is reloaded. The existing lock is not
tracked by the gc so would not be found by eventlet's
green_existing_locks().

Instead we group all monkey patching into utils function and apply
patching consistently across daemons and WSGI servers.

Co-Authored-By: Clay Gerrard <clay.gerrard@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Alistair Coles <alistairncoles@gmail.com>
Closes-Bug: #1380815
Change-Id: I6f35ad41414898fb7dc5da422f524eb52ff2940f
"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2023-04-10 21:12:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/1f99d8c5c7530e2252a8a45196e92b25f115d301', 'message': "Don't monkey patch logging on import

Previously swift.common.utils monkey patched logging.thread,
logging.threading, and logging._lock upon import with eventlet
threading modules, but that is no longer reasonable or necessary.

With py3, the existing logging._lock is not patched by eventlet,
unless the logging module is reloaded. The existing lock is not
tracked by the gc so would not be found by eventlet's
green_existing_locks().

Instead we group all monkey patching into utils function and apply
patching consistently across daemons and WSGI servers.

Co-Authored-By: Clay Gerrard <clay.gerrard@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Alistair Coles <alistairncoles@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Don't monkey patch logging on import

Previously swift.common.utils monkey patched logging.thread,
logging.threading, and logging._lock upon import with eventlet
threading modules, but that is no longer reasonable or necessary.

With py3, the existing logging._lock is not patched by eventlet,
unless the logging module is reloaded. The existing lock is not
tracked by the gc so would not be found by eventlet's
green_existing_locks().

Instead we group all monkey patching into utils function and apply
patching consistently across daemons and WSGI servers.

Co-Authored-By: Clay Gerrard <clay.gerrard@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Alistair Coles <alistairncoles@gmail.com>
Closes-Bug: #1380815
Change-Id: I6f35ad41414898fb7dc5da422f524eb52ff2940f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/10/457110/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def patch_logging(): """ Monkey patches the logging module's thread module globally. Only the first call does this, subsequent calls have no effect. """ if not hasattr(logging, "_patched"): logging.thread = eventlet.green.thread logging.threading = eventlet.green.threading logging._lock = logging.threading.RLock() logging._patched = True patch_logging()
deleted_lines: logging.thread = eventlet.green.thread logging.threading = eventlet.green.threading logging._lock = logging.threading.RLock()

commit_message:
proxy controller: always pass x-backend-* headers to backend

X-Backend-* headers were previously passed to the backend server with
only a subset of all request types:

* all object requests
* container GET, HEAD
* account GET, HEAD

In these cases, X-Backend-* headers were transferred to backend
requests implicitly as a consequence of *all* the headers in the
request that the proxy is handling being copied to the backend
request.

With this change, X-Backend-* headers are explicitly copied from the
request that the proxy is handling to the backend request, for every
request type.

Note: X-Backend-* headers are typically added to a request by the
proxy app or middleware, prior to creating a backend request.
X-Backend-* headers are removed from client requests by the gatekeeper
middleware, so clients cannot send X-Backend-* headers to backend
servers. An exception is an InternalClient that does not have
gatekeeper middleware, deliberately so that internal daemons such as
the sharder can send X-Backend-* headers to the backend servers.

Also, BaseController.generate_request_headers() is fixed to prevent
accessing a None type when transfer is True but the orig_req is None.

Change-Id: I05fb9a3e1c98d96bbe01da2ee28474e0f57297e6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/61/879361/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: # Use the additional headers first so they don't overwrite the headers # we require. headers = HeaderKeyDict(additional) if additional else HeaderKeyDict() if transfer: self.transfer_headers(orig_req.headers, headers) headers.setdefault('x-timestamp', Timestamp.now().internal) if orig_req:

commit_message:
Proxy: restructure cached listing shard ranges

Updating shard range cache has been restructured and upgraded to v2
which only persist the essential attributes in memcache (see
Related-Change). This is the following patch to restructure the
listing shard ranges cache for object listing in the same way.

UpgradeImpact
=============
The cache key for listing shard ranges in memcached is renamed
from 'shard-listing/<account>/<container>' to
'shard-listing-v2/<account>/<container>', and cache data is
changed to be a list of [lower bound, name]. As a result, this
will invalidate all existing listing shard ranges stored in the
memcache cluster.

Co-Authored-By: Alistair Coles <alistairncoles@gmail.com>
Related-Change: If98af569f99aa1ac79b9485ce9028fdd8d22576b
Change-Id: I54a32fd16e3d02b00c18b769c6f675bae3ba8e01
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/39/876939/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cache_key = 'shard-%s-v2/%s/%s' % (shard, account, container)
deleted_lines: if shard == 'updating': cache_key = 'shard-%s-v2/%s/%s' % (shard, account, container) else: cache_key = 'shard-%s/%s/%s' % (shard, account, container)

commit_message:
ECFragGetter: assume policy.fragment_size is non-zero

Simplify ECFragGetter by removing code that guards against the policy
fragment_size being None or zero.

Policy fragment_size must be > 0: the fragment_size is based on the
ec_segment_size, which is verified as > 0 when constructing an EC
policy. This is asserted by test_parse_storage_policies in
test.unit.common.test_storage_policy.TestStoragePolicies.

Also, rename client_chunk_size to fragment_size for clarity.

Change-Id: Ie1efaab3bd0510275d534b5c023cb73c98bec90d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/47/881547/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: self.client_chunk_size = policy.fragment_size If client_chunk_size is set, makes sure we yield things starting on chunk boundaries based on the Content-Range header in the response. if self.client_chunk_size: self.skip_bytes = bytes_to_skip(self.client_chunk_size, start) client_chunk_size = self.client_chunk_size or len(buf) while buf and (len(buf) >= client_chunk_size or not chunk): client_chunk = buf[:client_chunk_size] buf = buf[client_chunk_size:]

commit_message:
Update
"test_list_migrations_in_flavor_resize_situation" to indicate the failing request on timeout.

This is one of those tests that for some reason or the other fail randomly on our CI systems. Problem is, that the error message it fails with is not very helpful, as it just indicates that a timeout happened but not much else. This change seeks to fix that by including the request id that led to the timeout. This way, once the test fails on a build, it will be possible to search the log files for this request and track the underlying problem.

Closes-Bug: #2009701
Change-Id: Ic1ffd62f9d6ed0d69467f678c1820cddbb1fda12

commit_message:
Update url

The OpenStack project is currently maintained on opendev.org, with github.com serving as a mirror repository.

Replace the source code repository address for the python-swiftclient project from github.com to opendev.org.

Change-Id: I650a80cb45febc457c42360061faf3a9799e6131
(cherry picked from commit 5032b42b10548bda6d27dba81cfec2f95a67d91b)

commit_message:
Fix faulty precheck for RabbitMQ

When using externally managed certificates, according to [1],
one should set `kolla_externally_managed_cert: yes` and ensure
that the certificates are in the correct place.

However, RabbitMQ precheck still expects the certificates to be
available on the controller node. This is incorrect.

Fix by not running the tasks in question when `kolla_externally_managed_cert: yes`

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/kolla-ansible/latest/admin/tls.html

Closes-Bug: 1999081
Related-Bug: 1940286
Signed-off-by: Magnus Lf <magnus.loof@basalt.se>
Change-Id: I9f845a7bdf5055165e199ab1887ed3ccbfb9d808
(cherry picked from commit fdacf9d1d9819f3d9ebe4c2bbdace11b502086a9)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/19/881319/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - not kolla_externally_managed_cert | bool - not kolla_externally_managed_cert | bool - not kolla_externally_managed_cert | bool - not kolla_externally_managed_cert | bool

commit_message:
Make all config parsing case-sensitive

This effects both daemon config parsing and paste-deploy config parsing
when using conf.d.  When the WSGI servers were loaded from a flat file
they have always been case-sensitive.  This difference was surprising
(who wants anything case-insensitive?) and potentially dangerous for
values like RECLAIM_AGE.

UpgradeImpact:

Previously the option keys in swift's configuration .ini files were
sometimes parsed in a case-insensitive manner, so you could use
CLIENT_TIMEOUT and the daemons would recognize you meant client_timeout.
Now upper-case or mixed-case option names, such as CLIENT_TIMEOUT or
Client_Timeout, will be ignored.

Change-Id: Idd8e552d9fe98b84d7cee1adfa431ea3ae93345d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/13/879513/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: client_timeout = 1

commit_message:
Sync neutron db to ovn nb db when neutron-server start

Neutron server default only log warning when ovn north-bound's db
mismatched with neutron's db. This patch enable auto sync neutron
db to ovn nb db when neutron-server start.

Reference code:
https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/neutron/conf/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/ovn_conf.py#L98

Change-Id: I005425ce533f48b2c25b28b47b22e94d054e68d2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm refs/changes/93/881293/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: neutron_sync_mode: repair

subject: Add pysnmp-lextudio and pyasn1-lextudio
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-04-26 09:08:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/e79d6d6d7a912b278c53551fc9c479e88eeef707', 'message': "Add pysnmplib

The pysnmp library is not maintained since 4 years and it's
now incompatible with other related libraries like pyasn1.
Deprecate it and add its fork pysnmplib.

Change-Id: I90274181c1e027d9b17a556fa1ac4767cbf6b5d0
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2023-04-27 13:55:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/68b95f7f0f1016cadf2ce18b8e618729099742c2', 'message': "Add pysnmp-lextudio and pyasn1-lextudio

The pysnmp library is not maintained since 4 years and it's
now incompatible with other related libraries like pyasn1.
Deprecate it and add its fork pysnmp-lextudio with its
dependency pyasn1-lextudio

For more info on the new pysnmp ecosystem please look at
https://github.com/etingof/pysnmp/issues/429

Change-Id: I90274181c1e027d9b17a556fa1ac4767cbf6b5d0
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2023-04-27 14:19:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/8995e26b5efb04afbd0047b133e93bb9625371f1', 'message': "Add pysnmp-lextudio and pyasn1-lextudio

The pysnmp library is not maintained since 4 years and it's
now incompatible with other related libraries like pyasn1.
Deprecate it and add its fork pysnmp-lextudio with its
dependency pyasn1-lextudio

For more info on the new pysnmp ecosystem please look at
https://github.com/etingof/pysnmp/issues/429

[Q] Is the library actively maintained?
[A] Yes.

[Q] Is the library good code?
[A] Yes.

[Q] Is the library python 3 compatible?
[A] Yes.

[Q] Is the library license compatible?
[A] Yes. BSD

[Q] Is the library already packaged in the distros we target
    (Ubuntu latest / Fedora latest)?
[A] No.

[Q] Is the function of this library already covered by other
    libraries in global-requirements.txt?
[A] Yes, but they're unmaintained or not part of the same ecosystem, which brings
    incompatibility in the long term (see the issue with pyasn1 0.5.0 update that
    is incompatible with pysnmp, even if it is one of its dependencies!)

Change-Id: I90274181c1e027d9b17a556fa1ac4767cbf6b5d0

"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2023-04-28 07:24:18.000000000', 'files': ['global-requirements.txt', 'upper-constraints.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/d875d3d4dd744c3b183e80810cf60b70ae8fb5d6', 'message': "Add pysnmp-lextudio and pyasn1-lextudio

The pysnmp library is not maintained since 4 years and it's
now incompatible with other related libraries like pyasn1.
Deprecate it and add its fork pysnmp-lextudio with its
dependencies pyasn1-lextudio and pyasn1-modules-lextudio

For more info on the new pysnmp ecosystem please look at
https://github.com/etingof/pysnmp/issues/429

[A] Yes.

[Q] Is the library good code?
[A] Yes.

[Q] Is the library python 3 compatible?
[A] Yes.

[Q] Is the library license compatible?
[A] Yes. BSD

[Q] Is the library already packaged in the distros we target
    (Ubuntu latest / Fedora latest)?
[A] No.

[Q] Is the function of this library already covered by other

[A] Yes, but they're unmaintained or not part of the same ecosystem,

    pyasn1 0.5.0 update that is incompatible with pysnmp, even if it
